alternatives.transcript: Hi, I'm Jacques Pepin, and I'm cooking at home. Sometimes I do a drink, and I want to show you a couple of drinks that I do at home. The first 1 is a very classic Kyr. Kyr, K-I-R, is named after a former mayor of Dijon, which is a town in Burgundy in France, where they do a lot of syrup. So you use creme de cassis, which is a blackcurrant syrup. See, I have here maybe a tablespoon at the most, and with a dry white wine on top of it, about that much. And this is what you call a kia. I have to say that my wife always put a couple of pieces of ice in it. And it's OK. They're not classic, but it's OK. So to you. The second 1, when I came to this country, I was introduced to Manhattan. I love Manhattan, too. But I end up doing what I call a reverse Manhattan. Manhattan, it's about 2 3rd whiskey. And the whiskey is usually an alcohol. It's an alcohol made of grain, whether it's barley, or rye, corn, and so forth. And a third, red vermouth. So I do kind of the reverse with a lot of ice. So Here is my reverse, my reverse Manhattan. A lot of ice in there. A piece of lime. This way. In there. And then red vermouth. And as you can see, I'm very generous with red vermouth. Red vermouth is basically the whole drink. You can put more, you can put less. You can, I mean, you know, doing the way you like? And I have a beautiful whiskey here, bourbon, so I have maybe 1 and 1 1⁄2 tablespoon of it in the mixture. So this is my reverse Marantan. And then finally, 1 thing we do in France, when you're cold, winter, if you have a cold, the thing you do, you do what we call a grog, G-R-O-G. And it is with rum, dark rum, and all that. And if you take an aspirin And you're grog, you go to bed, you feel like a million dollars a day after. So first you start with lemon. I would a good like a couple of tablespoon of lemon juice in there. And you can put the lemon. I would want to put probably a good 1, probably 2 tablespoons of sugar, like a quarter of a cup of a dark rum. And I have a very good dark rum here. You know that you mix a little bit and a good cup, cup and a half of boiling water. That's it. You have your cold, you drink this, go to bed, you feel like a million dollar the week after. I hope you

paragraphs.transcript:
Hi, I'm Jacques Pepin, and I'm cooking at home. Sometimes I do a drink, and I want to show you a couple of drinks that I do at home. The first 1 is a very classic Kyr. Kyr, K-I-R, is named after a former mayor of Dijon, which is a town in Burgundy in France, where they do a lot of syrup. So you use creme de cassis, which is a blackcurrant syrup.

See, I have here maybe a tablespoon at the most, and with a dry white wine on top of it, about that much. And this is what you call a kia. I have to say that my wife always put a couple of pieces of ice in it. And it's OK. They're not classic, but it's OK.

So to you. The second 1, when I came to this country, I was introduced to Manhattan. I love Manhattan, too. But I end up doing what I call a reverse Manhattan. Manhattan, it's about 2 3rd whiskey.

And the whiskey is usually an alcohol. It's an alcohol made of grain, whether it's barley, or rye, corn, and so forth. And a third, red vermouth. So I do kind of the reverse with a lot of ice. So Here is my reverse, my reverse Manhattan.

A lot of ice in there. A piece of lime. This way. In there. And then red vermouth.

And as you can see, I'm very generous with red vermouth. Red vermouth is basically the whole drink. You can put more, you can put less. You can, I mean, you know, doing the way you like? And I have a beautiful whiskey here, bourbon, so I have maybe 1 and 1 1⁄2 tablespoon of it in the mixture.

So this is my reverse Marantan. And then finally, 1 thing we do in France, when you're cold, winter, if you have a cold, the thing you do, you do what we call a grog, G-R-O-G. And it is with rum, dark rum, and all that. And if you take an aspirin And you're grog, you go to bed, you feel like a million dollars a day after. So first you start with lemon.

I would a good like a couple of tablespoon of lemon juice in there. And you can put the lemon. I would want to put probably a good 1, probably 2 tablespoons of sugar, like a quarter of a cup of a dark rum. And I have a very good dark rum here. You know that you mix a little bit and a good cup, cup and a half of boiling water.

That's it. You have your cold, you drink this, go to bed, you feel like a million dollar the week after. I hope you

sentences.text: Hi, I'm Jacques Pepin, and I'm cooking at home.
Sometimes I do a drink, and I want to show you a couple of drinks that I do at home.
The first 1 is a very classic Kyr.
Kyr, K-I-R, is named after a former mayor of Dijon, which is a town in Burgundy in France, where they do a lot of syrup.
So you use creme de cassis, which is a blackcurrant syrup.
See, I have here maybe a tablespoon at the most, and with a dry white wine on top of it, about that much.
And this is what you call a kia.
I have to say that my wife always put a couple of pieces of ice in it.
And it's OK.
They're not classic, but it's OK.
So to you.
The second 1, when I came to this country, I was introduced to Manhattan.
I love Manhattan, too.
But I end up doing what I call a reverse Manhattan.
Manhattan, it's about 2 3rd whiskey.
And the whiskey is usually an alcohol.
It's an alcohol made of grain, whether it's barley, or rye, corn, and so forth.
And a third, red vermouth.
So I do kind of the reverse with a lot of ice.
So Here is my reverse, my reverse Manhattan.
A lot of ice in there.
A piece of lime.
This way.
In there.
And then red vermouth.
And as you can see, I'm very generous with red vermouth.
Red vermouth is basically the whole drink.
You can put more, you can put less.
You can, I mean, you know, doing the way you like?
And I have a beautiful whiskey here, bourbon, so I have maybe 1 and 1 1⁄2 tablespoon of it in the mixture.
So this is my reverse Marantan.
And then finally, 1 thing we do in France, when you're cold, winter, if you have a cold, the thing you do, you do what we call a grog, G-R-O-G.
And it is with rum, dark rum, and all that.
And if you take an aspirin And you're grog, you go to bed, you feel like a million dollars a day after.
So first you start with lemon.
I would a good like a couple of tablespoon of lemon juice in there.
And you can put the lemon.
I would want to put probably a good 1, probably 2 tablespoons of sugar, like a quarter of a cup of a dark rum.
And I have a very good dark rum here.
You know that you mix a little bit and a good cup, cup and a half of boiling water.
That's it.
You have your cold, you drink this, go to bed, you feel like a million dollar the week after.
I hope you
